arXiv reading on December 09, 2023 ​

1. X-Ray Constraints on the Hot Gaseous Corona of Edge-on Late-type Galaxies in Virgo ​

Main results and conclusions ​

    1. It presents a systematic study of the putative hot gas corona around late-type galaxies (LTGs) residing in the Virgo cluster, based on archival Chandra observations.
    1. Significant extraplanar diffuse X-ray (0.5–2 keV) emission is detected in only three LTGs (21 LTGs in total), which are also the three galaxies with the highest SFRs.

    1. The apparent paucity of hot gas coronae in the sampled Virgo LTGs might be understood as the net outcome of the long-lasting effect of ram pressure stripping exerted by the hot intra-cluster medium and in-disk star-forming activity acting on shorter timescales.

The origin of the hot gas corona ​

There are two main origins of the hot gas corona (sometimes called hot gas \textit{halo}):

    1. External origin: Dark matter collapses first and the baryon structure forms later in the ΛCDM paradigm. The formation of the baryon structure is continuously supplied by accretion of the intergalactic medium (IGM), through which accretion shocks and gravitational compression heat the in- fallen IGM heated to X-ray-emitting temperatures.
    1. Internal origin: Cool gas forms stars. The stellar winds and supernovae heats cool gas.
